properties.name: Bonsecours Market
properties.intro: Bonsecours Market is a grand neoclassical building that once served as Montreal’s main public market. Today, it hosts boutiques, galleries, and cultural events.

properties.name: Notre-Dame-de-Bon-Secours Chapel
properties.intro: Often called the “Sailors’ Church,” this chapel features model ships hanging from the ceiling and offers a serene place for reflection. It also includes a museum dedicated to its founder, Marguerite Bourgeoys.

properties.name: Château Ramezay
properties.intro: This former governor’s residence has been transformed into a museum showcasing life in early Montreal. Its period rooms and gardens offer a glimpse into the city’s colonial past.

properties.name: Nelson Monument
properties.intro: Standing prominently in Place Jacques-Cartier, this monument honors British naval hero Admiral Nelson. It is one of Montreal’s earliest public landmarks.

properties.name: Notre-Dame Basilica of Montreal
properties.intro: This basilica is known for its stunning Gothic Revival architecture and richly decorated interior. It remains a centerpiece of religious and cultural life in Montreal.

properties.name: Saint-Sulpice Seminary
properties.intro: The seminary is one of the oldest institutions in the city, with a distinctive clock and symmetrical façade. It reflects the influence of the Sulpician order on Montreal’s early development.

properties.name: Bank of Montreal
properties.intro: The Bank of Montreal’s main building impresses with its grand stone columns and stately design. It symbolizes the city’s long-standing role as a financial hub.

properties.name: Pointe-à-Callière
properties.year: Museum opened 1992, but site includes structures from 17th century
properties.intro: This museum sits at the birthplace of Montreal and offers a deep dive into the city’s archaeological and historical roots. Visitors can explore underground ruins and rotating exhibitions.

properties.name: Monument of pioneers
properties.intro: This sculpture honors Paul de Chomedey de Maisonneuve and the first settlers of Montreal. It stands as a tribute to the city's origins and early struggles.

properties.name: Old Customs House
properties.intro: Once used to oversee goods arriving by ship, this classical building reflects Montreal’s importance as a port city.

properties.name: Alfred Building
properties.intro: The Alfred Building showcases elegant Beaux-Arts architecture and contributes to the historic fabric of the neighborhood.
